markdownRemark.html:
I experience this recurring theme of emotions. When this began the emotions were intense and stayed with me for prolonged intervals. Sometimes I couldn’t shake the feeling for months. These days something on the internet might “trigger” that feeling for me. But it is milder and I’m able to snap out of it quicker.

The emotions I’m referring to have to do with the experience of a deep loss. The kind of loss that strips away your identity. In the aftermath of which one is torn between unwanted inexorable reinvention and the holding onto of the loss.

A huge portion of my identity was devoted to being a student. That meant I genuinely enjoyed going to class, making notes, working on assignments, discussions with peers and professors, and taking tests. I derived a lot of satisfaction, joy, meaning, and purpose as a student. I was ecstatic to be in my Masters program in a area that truly excited me. It was a everything to me. I loved being pushed to my limits on challenging assignments by my professors even though in the moment it seemed stressful and undoable. I loved how students would organize themselves to discuss the test once it was completed. I loved the process of interviewing for internships. I’m not sorry, I just really enjoyed interviewing at that time. There was such possibility as I looked at postings for the open roles.

In December 2019 I accepted the internship for what was supposed to be a 4 month long hackathon / case competition in Toronto the summer of 2020. To say I was looking forward to that experience would have been an understatement. I knew this was my one and only window to experience being an intern, so this meant a lot to me.

Winter turned to spring and on 1 February 2020 as the Diamond Princess was quarantined in Okinawa the world I was excitedly looking forward to disappeared over night. At the time I couldn’t have fathomed that a far away procedural quarantine of a cruise ship off the coast of Japan would derail my plans and alter the course of my own life and a million others.

Now, something I learned in therapy was to stop disqualifying my feelings because somebody else has it worse. So I realize the immense toll that the virus has had in different ways. This is my story.
